The game has twelve regular rounds for the twelve months and the final round on the New Year's day. Just like people in Edo used to say that "fights and fires are the flower of Edo", there happens huge fires every now and then, so it's important to gather firefighting power to avoid risking to lose your businesses.

![Cylinders lining up](https://img.nippondering.com/612ae77f-8cd4-47c6-acb0-b8a038ca4a71.jpg)
##### *The cylindrical pieces decide how many moves each player can make during the second phase*

Each round has two phase: Phase 1 to "decide the way of life" and Phase 2 to "take actions". In the first phase, each person decide how many spaces Oyakata(boss=you) move forward during the second phase. This decision simultaneously determines the playing order for the second phase as well. 

In the second phase, there are two steps. The first step is to choose either hire an artisan or receive a payment of 4 Mon. The second step is to move Oyakata figure forward and buy/trade. 

![Artisan cards placed on the board](https://img.nippondering.com/1d1ba44d-959c-4ee8-b83c-95d309ed176e.jpg)
##### *Here you see that the purple Kobun will retire the second time you reach the starting point*

When you buy hire an artisan, keep in mind that you have to pay him/her a salary with one rice bale every three months. If you fails to pay the salary, the artisan will leave you. Besides, you can only have four Kobun working at the same time, meaning that there can only be up to four artisan cards on the board at the same time. However, each time you come back to the starting point, you can upgrade your Kobun. When you have upgraded him/her for three times, you can take the artisan card off the board and keep it for yourself. Then it no longer requires a salary or risks being burned down.

![Building cards](https://img.nippondering.com/18d2b0a8-f1cf-470c-b2a3-283fdd7eb837.jpg)
##### *You can buy a building with logs and Koban (Japanese old currency) during your second phase.*

Every three months, you have to pay a salary to the artisans (as mentioned above). At the same time, you can receive a profit and bonus. In the end of the game, we calculate all the IKI you have collected throughout the game. Cigarets, fishes, buildings, resources and artisan cards add some IKI points too.

Playing a board game is super fun. Why not also learn something while having fun? :D After you have played it, I´m sure you will be more interested in Japanese culture and history. Then you are more than ready to pay a visit to this interesting country. Possibly with me as a guide. Hehe.

posts.title: The 3 things you must eat in Sapporo
posts.summary: Sapporo offers a lot of unique yet addictively delicious foods. Here is the list of 3 things you must eat while in Sapporo, Hokkaido.
posts.content:
Have you ever been to Sapporo? Sapporo is the prefectural capital of Hokkaido, the northern island in Japan. Last month I traveled to Sapporo for the first time, and I found out that it offers a lot of unique yet addictively delicious foods. Let me introduce 3 things you must eat while you’re in Sapporo!

# ① Jingisukan
　Jingisukan is grilled mutton or lamb meats served with vegetables on a special dome-shaped grill pot, and it is one of the local cuisines of Hokkaido.
The name of the cuisine is thought to derive from Genghis Khan, who is the first emperor of the Mongol Empire, because grilled mutton and lamb meats were often eaten by him and the warriors of the Empire.

　However, there’s no cuisine served like this in Mongolia so we can say Jingisukan is something you can only eat in Hokkaido(and some other places in Japan)!

![Daruma](https://img.nippondering.com/61dbbc35-972e-45a6-a273-f6196608414b.jpg)
##### *Daruma, the most popular Jingisukan restaurant in Sapporo*

　The restaurant I went to have Jingisukan is called “Daruma”.  This restaurant was established in 1954 and currently has 5 branches within Sapporo city. They have been offering the unchanged taste of Jingisukan with fresh mutton meats and the secret sauce since their establishment.

![Jingisukan](https://img.nippondering.com/270f0fe9-6f05-4064-bf90-85f00ec672ee.jpg)
##### *Fresh mutton meats with vegetables*

　And here it is, Jingisukan! In Daruma, you will get a big serving of onions and green onions for free if you order any muttons. You can grill mutton meats on the top first and then grill these veggies at the bottom with the oil that comes out of the meats. Their secret sauce is also outstanding and definitely a perfect match for the meats and veggies!

# ② Shime-Parfait
　Shime-Parfait, which literally means “parfait to call it a night”, is a new food culture originated in Sapporo. Nowadays there are a lot of places that offer parfait menu at night in Sapporo, and people of all ages in the city enjoy eating parfait after they finish their drinking sessions before going home.

　I tried my very first Shime-Parfait at “Parfait, coffee, liquor, Sato”. I know it’s a bit strange name, but it is one of the popular Shime-Parfait shops in Sapporo which is specialized to offer handmade parfait with the selection of coffees and alcoholic beverages.

![Shime-Parfait](https://img.nippondering.com/571459ba-a9f4-4c42-9eba-f0c2a09a7667.jpg)
##### *Salty caramels and pistachio parfait with a glass of whisky*

　I ordered salty caramels and pistachio parfait. Surprisingly, everything in the parfait, from ice cream to mousse, are all handmade. At first I honestly didn’t understand why people in Sapporo would have a parfait after drinking, but now I know why. It can sober you up refreshing your tongue and mind, and it just tastes SO GOOD to call it a night!

# ③ Ebisoba
　Last but not least, Sapporo is famous for its Miso-based Ramen(so-called Sapporo Ramen) but you can never forget to try Ebisoba when you visit Sapporo. Ebi means shrimp and Soba means noodles in Japanese, so literally Ebisoba is noodles in shrimp broth soup.

　You can find a lot of Ramen shops offering Ebisoba in Sapporo, but “Ebisoba Ichigen” is known as the best Ebisoba shop. They have 2 branches in the city, one is located in downtown Sapporo and the other is at New Chitose airport. I didn’t have enough time to go to the main shop in downtown Sapporo during my stay, but luckily I found the shop at the airport on my way back home and I got to try Ebisoba!

![Ichigen](https://img.nippondering.com/c856a9a1-5236-4d0d-b723-85dd73a5d3dd.jpg)
##### *Ichigen, the best Ebisoba shop*

　They only have 3 menus of Ramen; Ebi-shio(salt-based), Ebi-miso(Miso-based), and Ebi-Shoyu(soy-sauce-based). You can also choose the amount of pork bone broth you would like to add to the shrimp broth; no pork broth(shrimp broth only), just a little bit, or right amount, as well as the types of noodles; thin or thick.

![Ebisoba](https://img.nippondering.com/554c6851-d20a-45f0-b6b9-700d2a841f6b.jpg)
##### *Ebi-miso Ramen mixed with pork bone broth*

　It was my first time trying Ebisoba or any kind of noodles with shrimp broth, but I fell in love with it as soon as I had the first bite! Highly recommended and I guarantee you will never get disappointed!

　These are 3 things you shouldn’t miss when you visit Sapporo. Of course Sapporo offers a lot more of delicious foods as well as must-visit sightseeing spots, so why don’t you plan your next trip to Sapporo and fulfill your stomach and mind?

posts.title: What to do in Shirahama during winter
posts.summary: Try Kue fish and get astonished by the arts of nature. Enjoy hot spring in cold weather, with an ocean view. Shirahama isn't only for summer!
posts.content:
I have always wanted to try Kue fish, or longtooth grouper, but somehow never had a chance. Finally, I took a bus to Shirahama (Wakayama) and gave it a try. Amazing! Shirahama is usually a popular spot during summer because it has a beautiful beach. However, if you would like to try Kue fish, come during winter. Shirahama also has some nice spots to visit even in the cold weather :) Here is the list of what I saw and did in Shirahama. 

# 1) Indulge yourself in Sakino-yu
![Sakino-yu Hot Spring](https://img.nippondering.com/0a32df6f-0507-46d2-8825-cb0cc4b603c3.jpg)
##### *Be careful. Men's bathing place is wide open to visitors at the underwater observatory :D*

Sakino-yu offers a great experience of soaking yourself in Onsen (hot springs in Japanese) while feeling sea wind on your face. Shirahama hot spring is well known for being one of the oldest hot springs in Japan along with Arima hot spring in Kobe and Dōgo hot spring in Ehime. Feel the history of 1,000 years and watch the ocean stretching as far as your eyes can see. Your body will be fully rested and ready to go on adventure! Note that you must NOT use soap here. If you want to wash yourself, better to go to somewhere else first. 

# 2) Stroll around on Senjojiki
![Senjojiki, meaning "one thousand tatami mats" ](https://img.nippondering.com/88135300-0557-4694-8ba2-37896fe963ea.jpg)
##### *Me, yoga and Senjojiki*

Senjojiki, literally meaning "one thousand tatami mats" is a wonderful creation of our mother nature. Waves of the Pacific Ocean have eroded the coastline, resulting in this beautifully jagged rock formation. On the contrarily smooth surface, you can walk around and enjoy spectacular view! You can also take a nice yogini picture :D 


# 3) Explore Sandanbeki Cave
![Sandanbeki Cave](https://img.nippondering.com/69d7ca85-7f39-438e-bf74-febbe0022eb7.jpg)
##### *May this god bring you happiness :)*

Sandanbeki is a magnificent cliff with a historical cave. Go explore the cave and see where the pirates hid their boats. They contributed to the victory of the Genji clan over the Heishi clan at the end of Heian period (794-1185). You will also see a bronze statue of Murodai Benzaiten (deity of water) accompanied by his servants. This is the biggest statue of Benzaiten in Japan and will bring you happiness! 

# 4) Say hello to fishes from the underwater observatory
![the Underwater Observatory at Hotel Seamore](https://img.nippondering.com/a517e47d-3dcd-435d-a496-3caeb5c31043.jpg)
##### *Go down stairs and spot fishes or watch men bathing in Sakino-yu from here...*

This is the place where I visited to kill time before checking in the hotel. This observatory is honestly quite worn out, however you can have fun spotting some cute fishes. In spite that the sea was rough that day, I could still spot some fishes floating in the sea. Kids are having super fun anyway, so I recommend here especially for kids. Otherwise, pay a visit when the sea is calm. 

# 5) Get yourself into the hole of Engetsuto
![Engetsuto - "circle moon island"](https://img.nippondering.com/e7a1d142-1c0e-4e57-9690-21e2a87d6983.jpg)
##### *took some works to find the right spot, but worth it.*

You will again witness the art of mother nature here. Waves have somehow eroded the middle of this little island and shaped full moon hole just as the name Engetsuto - "circle moon island" suggests. If you want a best shot, wait for sunset. You can capture a moment where sun is fitting right in the hole. Otherwise, just fit yourself in!

# 6) Have some delicious Turkish food
![Pide at Tsugumi Cafe](https://img.nippondering.com/a01a002b-205d-409a-bd99-a90999089ef4.jpg)
##### *Pide at Tsugumi Cafe. A delicious Turkish pizza ;)*

Wakayama is where the basis for friendship between Japan and Turkey was first established. Ertuğrul ship from Turkey suffered shipwreck in 1890 off the coast of Kushimoto, Wakayama. The story of devoted rescue by the citizens at the time was passed down through generations in Turkey and Turkey saved more than 200 Japanese left in Iran under Iran-Iraq War in 1985. You see the hint of this precious friendship in Shirahama. At a Turkish cafe, Tsumugi Cafe, I enjoyed Turkish Pide and kebab, watching beautiful Turkish lamps. 

# 7) Feel rich in your private hot spring
![Private Hot Spring](https://img.nippondering.com/887a3813-e3bd-49a9-b1b2-88f59d7a6c88.jpg)
##### *Hot spring at my room. How can it get better?*

I stayed at a little cozy ryokan(Japanese style hotel), Yurakuan. It has only 6 rooms and all rooms come with a private hot spring. Not a normal water, real hot spring gushing out from the ground and directly poured into a wooden bathtub. Bathing in a private hot spring in cold weather is really a luxury. Thanks to this healing therapy, my skin became super smooth after taking a bath. Surprisingly, the cost isn't as high as you might expect. One night stay for two people including breakfast and dinner was only 52,800 yen (about 500 USD). Very reasonable for the wonderful experience you receive. 

# 8) And of course fill your stomach with Kue fish
![Kue fish course](https://img.nippondering.com/7f9b9ca3-2dec-4c04-a382-c21d61fe11f0.jpg)
##### *Kue fish course. Don't worry. This isn't everything.*
Finally, here is what I originally went for; Kue fish. I enjoyed a big Kue course menu at our hotel room. The portion was more than enough. I tried Kue fish in different forms, and my favorite was hot pot and Kamameshi(rice cooked in an iron pot). I could taste the rich sweet flavor of Kue fish best in these forms. You can try Kue fish at restaurants as well, but I recommend trying it at ryokans. It gives you better Japanese experience. And I mean, what's better than delicious meals delivered right to your room? 

It takes about three hours to Shirahama from Osaka on bus. I know it may not be the first place that comes up in your mind when planning a trip to Japan especially during winter. However, if you would like to see more than just the major cities and/or simply interested in delicious winter food, Shirahama is definitely recommended!
